issues.description: In the problem statement's UML diagram, numberOfInscribedStudents and numberOfGuestStudents are declared as double, but the solution (and likely the tests) use int for these fields and for the corresponding constructor parameters. Students implementing the double-typed attributes will conflict with the reference solution and test expectations.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML diagram in the problem statement so that numberOfInscribedStudents and numberOfGuestStudents are int instead of double, matching the intended implementation and tests.

issues.description: Within the problem statement's UML, getTotalNumberOfStudents() is specified to return int, yet it sums two attributes typed as double. This inconsistency may confuse students about whether the method should return int or double and how to handle any necessary type conversion.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the UML diagram by either changing the two student count attributes to int (so the sum naturally returns int) or by changing getTotalNumberOfStudents() to return double to match the declared attribute types.
